message_1: If there are 5 people who want to ride in a car that can only hold 3 people, how many different groups of 3 people can be selected to ride in the car?
message_2:
To determine the number of different groups of 3 people that can be selected from 5 people, we can use the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where C(n, k) represents the number of combinations, n is the total number of items, k is the number of items to be chosen, and ! denotes the factorial.

In this case, n = 5 (total number of people) and k = 3 (number of people to be chosen).

C(5, 3) = 5! / (3!(5-3)!)

C(5, 3) = 5! / (3!2!)

C(5, 3) = (5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(2 × 1))

C(5, 3) = (120) / (6 × 2)

C(5, 3) = 120 / 12

C(5, 3) = 10

So, there are 10 different groups of 3 people that can be selected to ride in the car.
